questions.question: What is structured cabling?

options.text: An ad-hoc cabling approach with no standard, often creating complex maintenance issues.
A standardized approach to designing, installing, and managing network cabling infrastructure in a consistent and organized manner.
A protocol suite that defines data, voice, and video encapsulation.
A set of wireless standards that define how signals are broadcast through air.

questions.explanation: A standardized approach to designing, installing, and managing network cabling infrastructure in a consistent and organized manner.

questions.question: Why is structured cabling important?

options.text: Because 70% of network problems are traced to cabling faults, and proper structure reduces failures and maintenance costs.
Because it replaces the need for documentation and labeling in network rooms.
Because it is required for all wireless networks to function correctly.
Because it guarantees zero electromagnetic interference on all copper cables.

questions.explanation: Because 70% of network problems are traced to cabling faults, and proper structure reduces failures and maintenance costs.

questions.question: What is unstructured cabling?

options.text: A method that divides the network infrastructure into manageable blocks.
A cabling plan defined by the EIA-568 standard for commercial buildings.
A cabling approach where no single standard is followed for interconnections, leading to complexity and maintenance issues.
A standardized approach to designing and managing cabling in a consistent way.

questions.explanation: A cabling approach where no single standard is followed for interconnections, leading to complexity and maintenance issues.

questions.question: What are the main disadvantages of unstructured cabling?

options.text: Low initial cost but higher long-term expenses; difficult maintenance and scalability; poor support for future technologies.
Prevents additions and moves unless the whole network is rewired.
Limited to fiber-optic links and cannot support copper cabling.
Low initial cost but higher long-term expenses; difficult maintenance and scalability; poor support for future technologies.

questions.explanation: Low initial cost but higher long-term expenses; difficult maintenance and scalability; poor support for future technologies.

questions.question: What are the benefits of structured cabling over unstructured cabling?

options.text: Better organization; easier maintenance; scalability; support for future technologies; lower long-term cost.
Improved signal propagation by reflecting radio waves off the ionosphere.
Lower initial cost and fewer standards to follow, making it faster to deploy.
Better for temporary setups because it avoids patch panels and labeling systems.

questions.explanation: Better organization; easier maintenance; scalability; support for future technologies; lower long-term cost.

questions.question: How does structured cabling organize infrastructure?

options.text: By converting DTE data into signals using physical-layer equipment.
By using only one long backbone cable shared by every device (bus layout).
By dividing the entire network infrastructure into manageable blocks.
By following no single standard so cables can be routed however is convenient.

questions.explanation: By dividing the entire network infrastructure into manageable blocks.

questions.question: What administrative advantages does structured cabling provide?

options.text: Labeling and color-coding for quick identification; clear documentation and management.
Using routers to separate broadcasts and select optimal paths.
Using parabolic dish antennas and horn antennas to focus transmissions.
Choosing network architecture and topology without any need for documentation.

questions.explanation: Labeling and color-coding for quick identification; clear documentation and management.

questions.question: How does structured cabling support changes in a network?

options.text: It prevents any cabling changes by locking the layout to the initial design.
It allows additions, moves, and changes with minimal inconvenience.
It supports changes by increasing the number of hubs allowed in a LAN.
It allows changes only if the entire trunk cable is replaced.

questions.explanation: It allows additions, moves, and changes with minimal inconvenience.

questions.question: What must be considered when choosing network cabling?

options.text: Only the cable connector type (RJ45 vs BNC) and the patch lead length.
Only whether the network uses DTE or DCE devices at the endpoints.
Network architecture (Ethernet, Token Ring); topology (star, bus, ring); building codes and regulations.
Only the IP addressing plan and routing protocol used in the network core.

questions.explanation: Network architecture (Ethernet, Token Ring); topology (star, bus, ring); building codes and regulations.

questions.question: What tools are required for proper cabling installation?

options.text: Parabolic dishes, horn antennas, and microwave repeaters.
Routers, switches, and firewalls for broadcast separation.
Oscilloscopes, spectrum analyzers, and RF power meters.
Crimpers; fish tapes; continuity testers; labeling tools.

questions.explanation: Crimpers; fish tapes; continuity testers; labeling tools.

questions.question: Why is documentation important in structured cabling?

options.text: It enables easy maintenance, troubleshooting, and future upgrades.
It ensures network devices can communicate directly without any DCE.
It enables easy maintenance, troubleshooting, and future upgrades.
It eliminates the need for patch panels and labeling in equipment rooms.

questions.explanation: It enables easy maintenance, troubleshooting, and future upgrades.

questions.question: What does the TIA/EIA 568A standard specify?

options.text: How routers select optimal paths and converge quickly after failures.
Maximum distances for horizontal wiring; cable parameters such as crosstalk and attenuation; cabling structure (e.g. star); connectors (RJ45); equipment rooms and closets.
How DTE devices translate digital and analog signals using modems.
Maximum microwave transmission distance between ground stations.

questions.explanation: Maximum distances for horizontal wiring; cable parameters such as crosstalk and attenuation; cabling structure (e.g. star); connectors (RJ45); equipment rooms and closets.

questions.question: Who published the EIA-568 standard and when?

options.text: The Electronics Industries Association published EIA-568 in 1991.
The IEEE published it in 1985 as part of the Ethernet standards.
The IETF published it as an RFC to standardize wireless cabling.
The International Telecommunication Union published it in 2001.

questions.explanation: The Electronics Industries Association published EIA-568 in 1991.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the EIA-568 standard?

options.text: To specify radio and microwave frequency bands regulated by governments.
To describe how token passing prevents collisions in ring networks.
To define cabling requirements for commercial building telecommunications.
To define packet routing requirements between different LANs.

questions.explanation: To define cabling requirements for commercial building telecommunications.

questions.question: What type of cabling does EIA-568 specify?

options.text: Only coaxial cable types used in 10Base-2 and 10Base-5 Ethernet.
Voice-grade unshielded twisted pair (UTP); shielded twisted pair (STP) for in-building applications.
Only fiber-optic cabling connectors such as SC and ST.
Any unguided media used for microwave and infrared transmission.

questions.explanation: Voice-grade unshielded twisted pair (UTP); shielded twisted pair (STP) for in-building applications.

questions.question: What is Data Terminal Equipment (DTE)?

options.text: Any device that acts as a source or destination of binary digital data and does not communicate directly with other DTEs.
Equipment that converts DTE data into physical signals at the physical layer.
Any device that acts as a source or destination of binary digital data and does not communicate directly with other DTEs.
A cabling method that follows no standard, increasing maintenance issues.

questions.explanation: Any device that acts as a source or destination of binary digital data and does not communicate directly with other DTEs.

questions.question: How is DTE explained using an analogy?

options.text: Like a modem translating digital and analog signals for transmission.
Like a brain that generates ideas but cannot transmit them directly without a translator.
Like a router selecting the optimal path for packets between networks.
Like a patch panel that organizes and labels cables in a cabinet.

questions.explanation: Like a brain that generates ideas but cannot transmit them directly without a translator.

questions.question: What is Data Circuit-Terminating Equipment (DCE)?

options.text: Any device that acts as a source or destination of binary digital data.
Equipment that receives or transmits data signals (analog or digital) and works at the physical layer of the OSI model.
A labeling system used to color-code cables for quick identification.
Equipment that receives or transmits data signals (analog or digital) and works at the physical layer of the OSI model.

questions.explanation: Equipment that receives or transmits data signals (analog or digital) and works at the physical layer of the OSI model.

questions.question: What is the role of DCE in networking?

options.text: It converts data from DTE into signals that can be transmitted over a communication link.
It selects optimal routes and separates broadcasts between VLANs.
It defines maximum distances for horizontal wiring in a building.
It converts data from DTE into signals that can be transmitted over a communication link.

questions.explanation: It converts data from DTE into signals that can be transmitted over a communication link.

questions.question: What is a common example of DCE?

options.text: An RJ45 patch panel used to connect outlets to switches.
A modem that translates between digital and analog signals.
A trunking system used to route and protect cables.
A continuity tester used to verify cable integrity.

questions.explanation: A modem that translates between digital and analog signals.

questions.question: At which OSI layer does DCE operate?

options.text: The Application Layer.
The Data Link Layer.
The Physical Layer.
The Network Layer.

questions.explanation: The Physical Layer.

questions.question: What are the main advantages of structured cabling?

options.text: Broadcast separation and optimal path selection by routing protocols.
Guaranteed lowest initial cost and no need for standards or planning.
Consistency for data, voice, and video; multi-vendor support; simplified troubleshooting; support for future applications; fault isolation; reduced maintenance costs.
High bandwidth wireless transmission using parabolic dish antennas.

questions.explanation: Consistency for data, voice, and video; multi-vendor support; simplified troubleshooting; support for future applications; fault isolation; reduced maintenance costs.

questions.question: How does structured cabling simplify troubleshooting?

options.text: Problems are broadcast to all nodes so every device can help diagnose them.
Troubleshooting requires rewiring the entire trunk to isolate faults.
Problems are easier to isolate and fix without affecting the entire network.
Troubleshooting relies on ionosphere conditions and time of day.

questions.explanation: Problems are easier to isolate and fix without affecting the entire network.

questions.question: How does structured cabling support future applications?

options.text: It supports multimedia, video conferencing, and new technologies with minimal upgrades.
It supports only voice services and cannot support multimedia or video.
It supports future tech by removing the need for labeling and documentation.
It supports multimedia, video conferencing, and new technologies with minimal upgrades.

questions.explanation: It supports multimedia, video conferencing, and new technologies with minimal upgrades.

questions.question: What equipment is typically included in a structured cabling setup?

options.text: Network cabinet; RJ45 patch panels; Cat 5e cables; outlets and backboxes; patch leads and fly leads; trunking and labeling systems.
Parabolic dishes, horn antennas, and aligned towers for microwave links.
Network cabinet; RJ45 patch panels; Cat 5e cables; outlets and backboxes; patch leads and fly leads; trunking and labeling systems.
Modems, routers, and switches used to connect different LANs together.

questions.explanation: Network cabinet; RJ45 patch panels; Cat 5e cables; outlets and backboxes; patch leads and fly leads; trunking and labeling systems.

questions.question: What is the main summary of structured cabling?

options.text: It is a wireless-only approach based on line-of-sight propagation.
It provides standardized installation and management of network cabling, guided by TIA/EIA standards, offering cost savings and performance benefits.
It is a routing design that focuses on optimal path selection and convergence.
It is an unstructured approach that avoids standards to reduce initial cost.

questions.explanation: It provides standardized installation and management of network cabling, guided by TIA/EIA standards, offering cost savings and performance benefits.

questions.question: Why do some organizations avoid structured cabling standards?

options.text: Because documentation is not allowed under TIA/EIA cabling guidelines.
Because structured cabling cannot support future technologies like video.
Due to higher initial costs, lack of awareness, or short-term cost-saving decisions.
Because standards make troubleshooting impossible and increase downtime.

questions.explanation: Due to higher initial costs, lack of awareness, or short-term cost-saving decisions.
